pageContent:
INFO 2950: 

Intro to Data Science


Lecture 21

2023-11-08

1

Agenda

1.
Naïve Bayes Classifier in action


2.
Logistic Regression (Review)


3.
Clustering


4.
Phase IV/V rubric

2

Probabilities in the wild

●
So far, we’ve been using probabilistic thinking 
to support data arguments in...

3

Example: halloween candy

Which bowl did we grab candy from?

Categories: Houses

Observations: a list of candy brands from a bag

4

Example: Yelp reviews

Is this review positive or negative?

Categories: Positive, Negative

Observations: a list of words from a new review

5

Example: baby names

The US Social Security Administration published the 
frequency of given names for each year for all names that 
occur at least five times for anyone with a US social security 
number

P("David" | 1932) = # people with name David born in 1932 







# people born in 1932

6

Rank these in order by age in the 
United States

Carol  Emily  Lisa  Ruth

7

琀
琀

Probably...

Ruth > Carol > Lisa > Emily

8

9

Pr(name|year) peaks

Ruth

Carol

Lisa

Emily

Example: baby names

In which year were current 2950 students born?

Categories: Years, 1980-2010 (equally likely?)

Observations: a list of given names from the 2950 class roster


10

Example: baby names

In which year were current 2950 students born?

Categories: Years, 1980-2010 (equally likely?)

Observations: a list of given names from the 2950 class roster

Which year has the highest probability of generating the 
~200 names?


11

Can we guess the average birth 
year of 2950 students based only 
on given names?

1.
Yes, within 1-2 years

2.
Yes, within 5-10 years

3.
No, it's too random

12

琀
琀

In-class code example

def
 
year_log_prob
(
names
, 
year
):

   year_counts, year_total = year_data[year]

   seen = []

   unseen = []

   log_prob = 
0.0

   
for
 name 
in
 names:

       
if
 name 
in
 year_counts:

           log_prob += np.log(year_counts[name] / year_total)

           seen.append(name)

       
else
:

           log_prob += np.log(
4
 / year_total) 
#assume small number of uncommon names (4 per year)

           unseen.append(name)

   
return
 log_prob


def
 
plot_names
(
counter
, 
start_year
=
1970
, 
end_year
=
2020
):

   years = 
list
(
range
(start_year, end_year + 
1
))

   year_log_probs = [year_log_prob(counter, year) 
for
 year 
in
 years]


   student_age_df = pd.DataFrame({
"Year"
: years, 
"LogProb"
: year_log_probs})


   seaborn.lineplot(data=student_age_df,  x=
"Year"
, y=
"LogProb"
)


13

Calculate log of 
Pr(name | year)

In-class code example

def
 
year_log_prob
(
names
, 
year
):

   year_counts, year_total = year_data[year]

   seen = []

   unseen = []

   log_prob = 
0.0

   
for
 name 
in
 names:

       
if
 name 
in
 year_counts:

           log_prob += np.log(year_counts[name] / year_total)

           seen.append(name)

       
else
:

           log_prob += np.log(
4
 / year_total) 
#assume small number of uncommon names (4 per year)

           unseen.append(name)

   
return
 log_prob


def
 
plot_names
(
counter
, 
start_year
=
1970
, 
end_year
=
2020
):

   years = 
list
(
range
(start_year, end_year + 
1
))

   year_log_probs = [year_log_prob(counter, year) 
for
 year 
in
 years]


   student_age_df = pd.DataFrame({
"Year"
: years, 
"LogProb"
: year_log_probs})


   seaborn.lineplot(data=student_age_df,  x=
"Year"
, y=
"LogProb"
)


14

Plot the summed log 
probabilities given a 
list of names/counts 
called 
counter

plot_names(Counter([
"Khaleesi"
]), start_year=
1880
)


16

Post-Game of 
Thrones, the name 
Khaleesi got way 
more popular!

plot_names(Counter([
"Khaleesi"
]), start_year=
1880
)


17

The difference in log 
probabilities in 2020 vs. 
1960 is about -9 - (-14) = 5


So, the name Khaleesi was 
about e
5
 = 148 times more 
popular in 2020 than in 
1960!

plot_names(INFO2950StudentNamesFA23, start_year=
1880
)



18

plot_names(INFO2950StudentNamesFA23, start_year=
1880
)



19

A clear peak in the 
early 2000’s when 
students were 
born!

Naive Bayes for non-text data

●
We can use Naive Bayes for other sorts of 
classification, too!

○
For some 
dataframe with multiple inputs
 x:

■
Apply the independent x’s assumption 
in Bayes’ rule

■
Generate a contingency table

■
Calculate relevant probabilities

20

Naive Bayes for non-text data

21

https://www.machinelearningplus.com/predictive-modeling/how-naive-bayes-algorithm-works-with-example-and-full-code/

Why do we ignore the denominator and use “proportional to” for these 
probabilities?

Naive Bayes for non-text data

30

https://www.machinelearningplus.com/predictive-modeling/how-naive-bayes-algorithm-works-with-example-and-full-code/
 

P(Sleet | Freezing, Windy, Wet) 
흰
 4/5 * 7/10 * 9/10 * 1/2 = 0.252

P(Rain | Freezing, Windy, Wet) 
흰
 0

P(Other | Freezing, Windy, Wet) 
흰
 0.01875

Why do we ignore the denominator and use “proportional to” for these 
probabilities?


For all three of the conditional probabilities, the denominator would just 
normalize (i.e. divides by ~0.27) since 
P(Sleet|F,W,W)+P(Rain|F,W,W)+P(O|F,W,W)
 = 1

 0.01875

Why do we ignore the denominator and use “proportional to” for these 
probabilities?


For all three of the conditional probabilities, the denominator would just 
normalize (i.e. divides by ~0.27) since 
P(Sleet|F,W,W)+P(Rain|F,W,W)+P(O|F,W,W)
 = 1

0.252+0+0.01875 ≈ 0.27

Naive Bayes

●
Naive Bayes allows us to classify our outcomes


○
These can be binary (Sports / not sports) or 
multi-category (sleet / rain / other)


○
We calculate probabilities based on the 
frequencies of these categories in our data for 
each independent input x (whether x
i
’s are 
words or weather characteristics)

“classifying” with one other model in class

○

 (for binary output)!

How does Naive Bayes compare to logistic 
regression?

ɑ, β

Logistic Regression Refresher

49

Logistic Function

Goal
: to estimate whether our output is TRUE 
or FALSE

Logistic Function

Goal
: to estimate whether our output is TRUE 
or FALSE


Method
: Make our regression tell us about the 
probability (between 0 and 1) that y = TRUE.

Probability (between 0 and 1)

Logistic Function

Goal
: to estimate whether our output is TRUE 
or FALSE


Method
: Make our regression tell us about the 
probability (between 0 and 1) that y = TRUE.

To force our regression to give us an output 
between 0 and 1, we use a 
transformation
 on 
our regression’s prediction for

Logistic Regression Refresher

63

What does it mean to increase the log-odds ratio 
by 
some amount?


Increasing the log-odds ratio also means increasing 
the odds ratio (logarithm is monotonically 
increasing!)


If increasing x
1
 yields an increase in log-odds ratio, 
it’ll also increase the odds ratio.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logit

Flipping heads


Rolling a 1 on a 6-sided die


Which is more likely?

Rolling a 1 on a 6-sided die has 1:5 odds


Not rolling a 1 on a 6-sided die has 5:1 odds


Odds ratio = 1 
→
 as likely that 
y=TRUE (relative to y=FALSE)


Odds ratio < 1 
→
 less likely that 
y=TRUE (relative to y=FALSE)


Odds ratio > 1 
→
 more likely that 
y=TRUE (relative to y=FALSE)

is 
1 to _______, which is {
small, large
}

If the odds ratio is 100,000 to 1 (large), the 
log odds ratio is __________

Classification

●
We’ve learned about two methods (Naive Bayes

108

Classification

●
We’ve learned about two methods (Naive Bayes 
and logistic regression) to classify outcomes into 
discrete “classes”

○
Binary outcome 0/1

○
Weather type (sleet, rain, other)


●
What if we want to classify things, but we don’t 
know the actual “classes”?

109

Clustering!

110

●
Clustering allows you to classify your data rows, 
even if you don’t have an output variable

Clustering!

111

●
Clustering allows you to classify your data rows, 
even if you don’t have an output variable



This is called an “unsupervised learning” algorithm

Clustering!

112

●
Clustering allows you to classify your data rows, 
even if you don’t have an output variable



This is called an “unsupervised learning” algorithm

(as opposed to “supervised learning”, e.g. regressions 
where we have examples of the desired output)

Clustering!

113

●
Clustering allows you to classify your data rows, 
even if you don’t have an output variable


○
Algorithm Input
: the number of classes 
k


○
Algorithm Output
: 
k 
clusters of datapoints 
based on spatial distance from each other

Example: Netflix categories

114

https://www.whats-on-netflix.com/library/categories/

Iterative algorithm

If we knew the position of the K mean points, we could easily 
assign each data point to one of the K clusters

If we knew the assignment of data points to clusters, we could 
easily find the position of the K mean points


143

Iterative algorithm

If we knew the position of the K mean points, we could easily 
assign each data point to one of the K clusters

If we knew the assignment of data points to clusters, we could 
easily find the position of the K mean points

But at the start we don't know either one!

144

Iterative algorithm

1.
Pick K random points

2.
While not converged:

a.
Assign data points to nearest mean

b.
Set means to average of assigned data points

154

Dataset: Penguins

penguins_df = seaborn.load_dataset("penguins")

penguins_df = penguins_df.dropna()

penguins_df.head()


155

More than 2 dimensions

penguin_clusters = 
KMeans(n_clusters=3).fit(penguins_df[[

"bill_length_z", "bill_depth_z", 
"flipper_length_z", "body_mass_z"
 ]])


penguins_df["clusters"] = 
penguin_clusters.labels_


seaborn.scatterplot(data=penguins_df, 
x="bill_length_mm", y="bill_depth_mm", 
hue="clusters")


156

More than 2 dimensions

penguin_clusters = 
KMeans(n_clusters=3).fit(penguins_df[[

"bill_length_z", "bill_depth_z", 
"flipper_length_z", "body_mass_z"
 ]])


penguins_df["clusters"] = 
penguin_clusters.labels_


seaborn.scatterplot(data=penguins_df, 
x="bill_length_mm", y="bill_depth_mm", 
hue="clusters")

Choosing the number of clusters

Selecting K is a hard problem

Anyone who says they have a formula for 
deciding the "right" number is wrong

"
How do I choose K?
" is the single most frequent 
question Instructor Thalken has gotten in her 
career and there are no good answers

Try a few K values and see what makes sense 
and suits your specific needs
